neighborhoods.name: Vieille Ville
neighborhoods.character: Geneva's historic heart, perched on a hill overlooking the lake. Dominated by St. Pierre Cathedral, narrow cobblestone streets, hidden courtyards, fountains, antique shops, galleries, and traditional restaurants. Steeped in history, particularly related to the Reformation.

location.description: The historical core on the left bank of the Rhône River, centered around the cathedral.

history.overview: Site of early settlements, became a fortified town in Roman times. Rose to prominence during the Protestant Reformation under John Calvin in the 16th century, becoming the 'Protestant Rome'. Retains its medieval layout and significant historical buildings.
history.significance: The birthplace of Calvinism, center of the Reformation, showcasing Geneva's long history and its role in European religious and intellectual life.
notable_events: Roman settlement ('Genava')
Construction of St. Pierre Cathedral (starting 12th C)
John Calvin's arrival and Reformation leadership (mid-16th C)
Escalade celebration origin (1602)
Development as a center of watchmaking

transit: Tram and bus stops at the edges (e.g., Bel-Air, Molard, Rive, Stand)
practical_info.safety: Very safe, well-patrolled. Quiet at night compared to other central areas.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for exploring shops, museums, and historical sites. Evenings for atmospheric dining. Fête de l'Escalade (December) is a unique local event.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent, but involves hills and cobblestones. Comfortable shoes are essential.

known_for: St. Pierre Cathedral and views from towers
best_for: History buffs
First-time visitors
Photographers
Romantic strolls
Those seeking character and history

attractions.name: St. Pierre Cathedral
attractions.description: Dominant landmark of Geneva, blend of Gothic, Romanesque, and Neoclassical styles. Climb the towers for panoramic city and lake views. Visit the archaeological site underneath.
attractions.appeal: Historical significance (Calvin's church), architecture, views, archaeology.

attractions.name: Place du Bourg-de-Four
attractions.description: Geneva's oldest marketplace square, lined with cafes, restaurants, boutiques, and a central fountain. Perfect spot for people-watching.
attractions.appeal: Historic atmosphere, lively cafes, central meeting point.

attractions.name: Maison Tavel
attractions.description: Geneva's oldest private residence, now a museum showcasing urban history and daily life in old Geneva, including a large relief map.
attractions.appeal: Insight into Geneva's past, preserved medieval architecture.

dining.name: Old Town Restaurants
dining.known_for: Atmospheric settings in historic buildings, traditional dishes
dining.atmosphere: Ranges from cozy cellars (carnotzets) to elegant restaurants and lively cafes on Place du Bourg-de-Four.

dining.name: Cafés on Place du Bourg-de-Four
dining.atmosphere: Bustling during the day, especially in good weather.

activities.name: Explore Hidden Passages
activities.description: Wander off the main streets to discover narrow passages and hidden courtyards.

activities.name: Climb Cathedral Towers
activities.description: Ascend the North and South towers of St. Pierre Cathedral for breathtaking 360-degree views.

stay_here_if: You want to be immersed in Geneva's history and charm
You prioritize walkability and a central, atmospheric location
You enjoy exploring historic sites and museums
avoid_if: You prefer modern accommodation or vibrant late-night action
You need easy car access and parking (very restricted)
insider_tips: Look for the 'secret passages' (passages secrets) that connect streets.
Visit the Treille Promenade for the world's longest wooden bench and views over Bastions Park.
Attend an organ concert at the Cathedral if possible.

neighborhoods.name: Les Pâquis
neighborhoods.character: A vibrant, multicultural, and somewhat edgy neighborhood known for its diverse population, lively nightlife, proximity to the lake and main station, and its status as Geneva's red-light district. Offers a wide range of international restaurants, budget accommodation, and contrasts sharply with more staid parts of Geneva.

location.description: Located on the right bank of Lake Geneva, stretching north from the Mont Blanc bridge towards the International District.
landmarks: Grand Hôtel Kempinski / Hotel President Wilson (Luxury Hotels on Quai)
Quai Wilson / Quai du Mont-Blanc (Lakeside Promenades)
Rue de Berne / Rue de Monthoux (Centers of nightlife/red-light activity)

history.overview: Historically pastureland ('pâquis'), it developed rapidly in the 19th century with the arrival of the railway and tourism. Became known for hotels catering to visitors and later developed its reputation for nightlife and as a red-light district. Has long been a landing spot for immigrant communities.
history.significance: Represents Geneva's cosmopolitan and sometimes gritty side, a hub for nightlife, diverse cuisine, and lakeside recreation (Bains des Pâquis).
notable_events: Development linked to Cornavin Station and tourism
Establishment of lakeside hotels and promenades
Emergence as a nightlife and red-light district
Became a distinctly multicultural neighborhood

transit: Close to Cornavin Main Station (trains, trams, buses)
Served by buses within the neighborhood
practical_info.safety: Generally safe during the day. Can feel uncomfortable or unsafe for some at night due to visible prostitution, drug dealing, and boisterous nightlife, particularly on certain streets (e.g., Rue de Berne). Exercise caution and awareness, especially late at night.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for Bains des Pâquis, lakeside walks. Evenings for the diverse restaurant scene and nightlife.

known_for: Bains des Pâquis (iconic baths, beach, fondue)
Multicultural atmosphere and diverse food (ethnic eateries)
Proximity to the lake and train station
best_for: Nightlife seekers
Adventurous eaters seeking diverse, affordable food
Budget travelers
Visitors wanting proximity to station and lake
People watchers looking for urban diversity

attractions.name: Bains des Pâquis
attractions.description: Iconic lakeside establishment with swimming areas (summer), saunas, hammam, massages, and a popular, affordable restaurant/buvette famous for its fondue in winter.
attractions.appeal: Unique Geneva experience, relaxation, affordable food, great views.

attractions.name: Lakeside Promenade (Quai Wilson)
attractions.description: Stretches along the lake offering views of the Jet d'Eau, the Left Bank, and the mountains.
attractions.appeal: Pleasant walks, stunning views, people watching.

dining.name: Diverse Ethnic Restaurants
dining.cuisine: Wide variety - Ethiopian, Thai, Indian, Middle Eastern, Portuguese, etc.
dining.known_for: Authentic flavors, affordable prices, large selection
dining.atmosphere: Ranges from very basic eateries to more established restaurants.

dining.name: Buvette des Bains des Pâquis
dining.cuisine: Simple, fresh, local (Plat du jour), Fondue (winter)
dining.known_for: Excellent value, lakeside setting, popular fondue

activities.name: Relax at Bains des Pâquis
activities.description: Swim, sunbathe, use the sauna, get a massage, or simply enjoy a meal/drink by the lake.

activities.name: Explore Nightlife
activities.description: Discover the numerous bars, pubs, and clubs concentrated in the area.

stay_here_if: You prioritize nightlife and a lively, multicultural atmosphere
You want budget-friendly accommodation near the station and lake
You enjoy diverse and affordable international food
avoid_if: You seek peace and quiet, especially at night
You are uncomfortable with visible red-light district elements or a gritty urban feel
insider_tips: The Bains des Pâquis offers incredible value - don't miss it.
Walk along the quays towards Parc Mon Repos for lovely views and green space.
While generally safe, stick to main streets if walking alone late at night.

neighborhoods.name: Plainpalais
neighborhoods.character: A large, diverse neighborhood centered around the vast Plaine de Plainpalais diamond-shaped park/square. Known for its huge flea market and produce market, proximity to the university, vibrant student life, numerous bars and cafes, cultural venues (Grand Théâtre edge), and a generally unpretentious, lively atmosphere.

location.description: Southwest of the Old Town, centered on the large Plaine.

history.overview: Historically marshland outside the city walls, the Plaine was drained and used for military exercises and gatherings. Developed as a residential and commercial area in the 19th century, becoming closely linked with the University. The Plaine itself has always been a focal point for markets and events.
history.significance: Represents Geneva's student life, market culture, and a more down-to-earth, central living area. A major hub for public life and gatherings.
notable_events: Use as marshland and training ground
Hosting of markets and fairs
Development of surrounding residential areas
Close association with the University of Geneva

practical_info.safety: Generally very safe. Standard precautions needed during large markets/events due to crowds.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Market days (Tue/Fri/Sun) for the buzz. Evenings for the bar scene. Anytime for exploring.

known_for: Cultural venues (Grand Théâtre, Victoria Hall, MEG)
best_for: Market lovers (flea market especially)
Students and younger travelers
Those seeking a lively, central base without Old Town prices
Visitors interested in cultural venues

attractions.name: Plainpalais Market
attractions.description: One of Europe's largest flea markets (check days, often Wed/Sat/Sun) and a large produce/food market (Tue/Fri/Sun). Bustling atmosphere.
attractions.appeal: Bargain hunting, unique finds, fresh food, vibrant local scene.

attractions.name: Musée d'Ethnographie de Genève (MEG)
attractions.description: Award-winning modern building housing ethnographic collections from around the world.

attractions.name: Grand Théâtre de Genève
attractions.description: Geneva's main opera house, presenting opera, ballet, and recitals.

dining.name: Plainpalais Bars & Cafes
dining.cuisine: Cafe fare, Pub food, International snacks
dining.known_for: Student hangouts, relaxed atmosphere, terrace seating

dining.name: Restaurants around Plainpalais
dining.known_for: Variety of options catering to different budgets and tastes
dining.atmosphere: Ranges from simple student-friendly eateries to more established restaurants.

activities.name: Browse the Flea Market
activities.description: Spend hours searching for treasures at the sprawling flea market.

activities.name: Relax or Skate on the Plaine
activities.description: Enjoy the open space, watch the skaters, or just hang out.

stay_here_if: You enjoy lively, diverse neighborhoods with good transport
You want a central location with plenty of bars and casual eateries
avoid_if: You are looking for luxury or high-end boutiques
insider_tips: Check the specific days for the flea market vs. the produce market as they differ.
The streets radiating off the Plaine (like Rue de Carouge towards Carouge) have many interesting shops and cafes.
Plainpalais is the main hub for the 'Fête de la Musique' in June.

neighborhoods.name: Eaux-Vives
neighborhoods.character: A chic and pleasant neighborhood on the Left Bank known for its proximity to the Jet d'Eau, Parc La Grange and Parc des Eaux-Vives, upscale restaurants, trendy cafes, and independent shops. Offers a sophisticated yet relaxed atmosphere, popular with locals and expats.

location.description: Located on the Left Bank of Lake Geneva, east of the Old Town and south of the Jardin Anglais.
landmarks: Parc La Grange (Rose garden, Théâtre de l'Orangerie)

history.overview: Developed significantly in the 19th century as a desirable residential area close to the lake and city center. The large parks (former private estates) became public, adding to its appeal. The construction of the Jet d'Eau further cemented its identity.
history.significance: Combines elegant urban living with exceptional lakeside parks and recreation, home to one of Geneva's most famous landmarks (Jet d'Eau).
notable_events: Development as a residential district
Public opening of Parc La Grange and Parc des Eaux-Vives
Installation of the Jet d'Eau (current version 1891)
Opening of Eaux-Vives Léman Express station (2019)

transit: Served by trams (line 12 along Rue des Eaux-Vives) and buses
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Anytime. Summer is wonderful for the parks and lake access. Pleasant for strolling and dining year-round.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent, flat along the lake and main streets, slight inclines towards parks.

best_for: Visitors seeking a balance of city life and green spaces
Foodies looking for trendy dining spots
Families (parks, Baby Plage)
Those wanting a slightly quieter but still central and upscale base

attractions.name: Jet d'Eau
attractions.description: Geneva's iconic fountain propelling water 140 meters high. Visible from much of the city, best viewed from the Jardin Anglais, Bains des Pâquis, or Eaux-Vives jetty.
attractions.appeal: Symbol of Geneva, impressive sight (operates most days, weather permitting).

attractions.name: Parc La Grange & Parc des Eaux-Vives
attractions.description: Two large, beautiful adjoining parks offering lawns, ancient trees, stunning lake views, a famous rose garden (La Grange), ruins, and the Théâtre de l'Orangerie.
attractions.appeal: Relaxation, picnics, beautiful walks, floral displays, summer concerts.

attractions.name: Baby Plage
attractions.description: A small, popular sandy beach and grassy area right by the lake, ideal for relaxing and paddling.
attractions.appeal: Easy lake access, family-friendly relaxation spot.

dining.name: Eaux-Vives Restaurants & Cafes
dining.cuisine: Modern European, Italian, French, Asian, Healthy
dining.known_for: Trendy eateries, quality ingredients, chic ambiance, brunch spots
dining.atmosphere: Stylish and popular with locals, often with outdoor seating.

dining.name: Restaurant Parc des Eaux-Vives
dining.known_for: Stunning location in the park with lake views, historic building

activities.name: Walk or Picnic in the Parks
activities.description: Spend time exploring the vast Parc La Grange and Parc des Eaux-Vives.

activities.name: Explore Rue des Eaux-Vives
activities.description: Browse the independent shops and choose from the many cafes and restaurants.

stay_here_if: You want an elegant neighborhood with excellent parks and lake access
You appreciate trendy dining and boutique shopping
You prefer a slightly quieter but still central location
avoid_if: You are on a tight budget (generally upscale)
You seek intense nightlife or an edgy atmosphere
You need to be right next to the Old Town's historic sites
insider_tips: Check for free summer concerts ('Musiques en été') often held in Parc La Grange.
The rose garden in Parc La Grange is spectacular in early summer.
The new Eaux-Vives station makes accessing other parts of the region via Léman Express very easy.

neighborhoods.name: Carouge
neighborhoods.character: Often described as Geneva's 'Greenwich Village'. A distinct town within the city, designed by Italian architects in the 18th century, giving it a Mediterranean, bohemian feel. Known for its low-rise buildings, colorful shutters, artisan boutiques, independent designers, lively market, numerous cafes and restaurants with terraces, and relaxed atmosphere.

location.description: Located south of Plainpalais, across the Arve River.
landmarks: Rue Ancienne / Rue St-Victor / Rue St-Joseph (Main streets)

history.overview: Developed under the Kingdom of Sardinia in the late 18th century as a rival trading town to Geneva. Designed on a grid plan by Italian architects, fostering religious tolerance and attracting artisans. Retains much of its original architecture and independent spirit.
history.significance: A unique example of 18th-century urban planning with a distinct Mediterranean/Italianate character, known for its artistic and bohemian identity.
notable_events: Commissioned by the King of Sardinia (late 18th C)
Designed by Italian architects
Development as a tolerant trading center attracting artisans
Became part of Geneva canton (1816)
Maintained identity as an artistic, bohemian hub

transit: Served by trams (lines 12, 18 terminate/pass through) and buses
Short tram ride from central Geneva (Plainpalais, Bel-Air)
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Market days (Wed/Sat) for atmosphere. Spring/Summer for enjoying terraces. Evenings for restaurants and bars. Christmas Market is popular.

known_for: Lively cafes and restaurants with terraces
Place du Marché and its market
best_for: Shoppers seeking unique items (non-mainstream)
Visitors who enjoy cafe culture and relaxing on terraces
Architecture lovers interested in its unique design
Those wanting a charming, village-like feel close to the city

attractions.name: Place du Marché
attractions.description: The heart of Carouge, a beautiful square hosting a popular market (Wed/Sat) and surrounded by cafes and shops.
attractions.appeal: Focal point of Carouge life, market atmosphere, cafe culture.

attractions.name: Artisan Boutiques & Workshops
attractions.description: Numerous small shops selling handmade goods, designer clothing, jewelry, ceramics, and more, often with workshops visible.
attractions.appeal: Discover unique, locally made products, support independent creators.

attractions.name: Carouge Architecture
attractions.description: The distinct grid layout, low buildings, colorful shutters, hidden courtyards, and squares reflecting its Sardinian design origins.
attractions.appeal: Visually charming and unique within Geneva.

dining.name: Carouge Restaurants & Cafes
dining.known_for: Abundant terrace seating, quality ingredients, neighborhood gems
dining.atmosphere: Relaxed, convivial, popular with locals, ranging from casual bistros to more upscale options.

dining.name: Le Dix Vins / Le Flacon
dining.known_for: Well-regarded dining spots in Carouge, innovative cuisine
dining.atmosphere: Stylish but often retaining a relaxed Carouge vibe.

activities.name: Shopping for Unique Gifts
activities.description: Explore the myriad of independent boutiques for fashion, design, crafts, and jewelry.

activities.name: Relax at a Terrace Cafe
activities.description: Soak up the atmosphere on Place du Marché or a side street with coffee or a drink.

stay_here_if: You love charming, unique neighborhoods with a village feel
You enjoy browsing independent boutiques and artisan shops
You appreciate a relaxed atmosphere with plenty of cafes and restaurants
avoid_if: You need to be in the absolute center of Geneva (it's a short tram ride away)
You prefer large department stores or mainstream brands
You are looking for buzzing, late-night clubs
insider_tips: Explore the small courtyards hidden behind building entrances.
Visit during the 'Nocturnes' when shops stay open late (check dates).
The Cinema Bio shows independent and art-house films.

neighborhoods.name: Quartier International
neighborhoods.character: Home to the European headquarters of the United Nations (Palais des Nations) and numerous other international organizations (WHO, ILO, ICRC, etc.). Dominated by large office buildings, embassies, and parks. Feels distinct from the rest of Geneva, with a diplomatic and professional atmosphere.

location.description: Located on the Right Bank, northwest of the city center, stretching from near the lake up towards the airport.
landmarks: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Museum (MICR)
Parc Mon Repos / Parc Moynier / Perle du Lac

history.overview: Chosen as the headquarters for the League of Nations after WWI, leading to the construction of the vast Palais des Nations in the 1930s. After WWII, it became the European center for the newly formed United Nations. Numerous other international governmental and non-governmental organizations subsequently established their headquarters here, solidifying its role as a global hub for diplomacy and humanitarian action.
history.significance: 'International Geneva' - a major center for global governance, diplomacy, peace talks, and humanitarian work.
notable_events: Selection as League of Nations HQ (1920)
Construction of Palais des Nations (1929-1938)
Establishment as UN European HQ (1946)
Growth of numerous other international organizations
Hosting of major international conferences and negotiations

transit: Well-served by trams (line 15 terminates at Nations) and buses (e.g., lines 5, 8, 11, 22)
Walkable within the district, but distances between organizations can be significant
Easy access to/from Cornavin station and the airport by bus
practical_info.safety: Very safe, high security presence around international organizations.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Weekdays during working hours to visit museums or take a UN tour (check availability). Anytime for parks.
practical_info.walkability: Good, though spread out. Excellent parks for walking.

known_for: Beautiful large parks (Botanical Gardens, Perle du Lac)
best_for: Visitors interested in international relations and humanitarian work
Those wanting to visit the UN or Red Cross Museum
People who enjoy large parks and botanical gardens

attractions.name: Palais des Nations
attractions.description: The impressive European headquarters of the UN. Guided tours often available, showcasing assembly halls and diplomatic history (check booking requirements).
attractions.appeal: Insight into international diplomacy, significant architecture.

attractions.name: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Museum
attractions.description: Powerful museum dedicated to the history and work of the Red Cross/Red Crescent movement and humanitarian action.
attractions.appeal: Moving exhibits, understanding global humanitarian issues.

attractions.name: Jardin Botanique (Conservatory and Botanical Garden)
attractions.description: Extensive botanical gardens with diverse plant collections, greenhouses, and peaceful paths.

dining.name: Cafeterias/Restaurants near Organizations
dining.known_for: Catering to international staff, often busy at lunchtime
dining.atmosphere: Can range from functional cafeterias to more formal restaurants, often quiet outside weekday lunch hours.

dining.name: Restaurants in nearby Petit-Saconnex
dining.atmosphere: More of a local neighborhood feel.

activities.name: Take a UN Tour
activities.description: Join a guided tour of the Palais des Nations (must book in advance, check security requirements).

activities.name: Walk through the Parks
activities.description: Explore the chain of parks along the lake: Parc Mon Repos, Parc Moynier, Perle du Lac, and the Botanical Gardens.

stay_here_if: You are in Geneva for work related to international organizations
You prioritize easy access to the UN, museums, and parks in this area
You prefer a quieter, more professional atmosphere
avoid_if: You seek lively nightlife or extensive dining/shopping options
You want to be immersed in the historic Old Town or bohemian Carouge
You prefer neighborhoods with a strong local residential character
insider_tips: The 'Broken Chair' sculpture in Place des Nations is a powerful symbol against landmines.
Allow plenty of time for security checks if taking a UN tour.
The parks along the lake (Perle du Lac, etc.) offer stunning views and are less crowded than Jardin Anglais.

spring: Attend the Geneva International Motor Show (March, if running)
Witness the blooming tulips at Parc de l'Indépendance in Morges (nearby)
Watch or participate in the Geneva Marathon (May)
Explore the Botanical Gardens as plants come to life
Attend 'Fête de la Tulipe' events in Morges
summer: Swim in Lake Geneva at Bains des Pâquis, Genève Plage, or various public access points
Attend the Fête de la Musique (free concerts across the city - June)
Watch the Bol d'Or Mirabaud sailing race on Lake Geneva (June)
Enjoy free summer concerts 'Musiques en été' (various parks, e.g., Parc La Grange)
Take boat trips on Lake Geneva (cruises, Mouettes shuttles)
Experience the Fêtes de Genève fireworks and festivities (August)
Relax or picnic in Parc La Grange or Parc des Eaux-Vives
autumn: Visit the Carouge Market for seasonal produce
Attend cultural events as seasons begin (Opera, Theatre)
Explore vineyards during harvest season (Geneva countryside)
Walk through parks enjoying autumn colors (Bastions, Eaux-Vives)
Visit museums on cooler days (Art & History, Red Cross, Ethnography)
winter: Visit Christmas Markets (e.g., Jardin Anglais Noël au Jardin, Carouge)
Enjoy cheese fondue at Bains des Pâquis or traditional restaurants
Attend the Coupe de Noël open-water swim race (for hardy spectators!)
Go ice skating (seasonal rinks, e.g., Parc des Bastions, Carouge)
